metadata.case_name: Executor of Lakshmamma (Appellant) v. Respondent No.1

facts.text: Annaji Iyengar died in July 1903, leaving adopted son (appellant), daughters Gundamma and Lakshmamma.
Annaji executed gift deed Ex.D on February 16, 1902, gifting items 1 and 2 to Lakshmamma and her husband Sadagopalachar jointly.
Annaji executed will Ex.B2 on August 31, 1901, bequeathing hypothecation bonds worth Rs.10,320 to Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar with survivorship.
Sadagopalachar died in December 1908, married to Lakshmamma, had three children: son Narayana Iyengar (died Jan 14, 1944 without issue, widow Respondent 1), daughters Thirumalamma and Yadugiramma.
Sadagopalachar used Rs.10,320 from Annaji's will to purchase immovable properties including items 3 and 4.
Narayana Iyengar died January 14, 1944, without issue, leaving widow Respondent 1.
Thirumalamma (daughter of Lakshmamma) had son (weak intellect, died pending litigation) and daughters Neelu, Jaya, Padmini.

Yadugiramma (daughter of Lakshmamma) married Kalbagal Garudachar, had son Narasimha Iyengar (Respondent 5), daughter Lilly; Garudachar had son S.G. Kalbagal (Junior Kalbagal) from first wife; Jaya married Junior Kalbagal.

Appellant filed suit as sole executor of Lakshmamma's will Ex.A dated August 22, 1945, claiming declaration of her ownership of scheduled properties (5 items: lands at Hampapura and Arjunahalli, vacant site), possession against Respondent 1 for items 3-5, life interest for her in 1-2, Rs.2106 past mesne profits, future mesne profits.
Respondents 2-4 are sons of appellant; Respondent 5 is Narasimha Iyengar.

Trial court (SubJudge, Mysore, Dec 19, 1947): Annaji's will genuine with survivorship; gift deed no survivorship; items 3-4 purchased from joint income; Lakshmamma had half share; will Ex.A genuine for half share; decreed half share possession items 3-5, Rs.1050 mesne profits, future enquiry; parties bear costs.

High Court (Mysore, March 20, 1951): Will Ex.A not proved (Lakshmamma not sound mind, not her intentions); items 3-5 not from bequest/income; Lakshmamma transferred interest in gift deed properties to husband; suit dismissed; no costs.

Lakshmamma about 64 years old at will execution, resided Hampapur, went to Mandya for Junior Kalbagal's marriage, fell ill (paralysis left side), stayed; appellant visited, prepared draft in Mysore day before, dictated to scribe Chokkanna (PW3) on Aug 22, 1945 ~11am; read to her, signed 5 places, attested by PW1 Krishnamurthy Rao, PW2 Narasimha Iyengar; registered same day ~5:30pm; power of attorney Ex.EE also executed same day.

Will Ex.A contains elaborate preamble arguing Lakshmamma's absolute title (survivorship, joint purchases, Narayana alienated his share); bequests: life interest items 1-2 to R1, then to R2-4 and R5; item 3 to R5, item 4 to R2-4 with charges for legacies/charities Rs.5000; appellant executor.
Appellant in financial straits, indebted ~Rs.30,000 at relevant time.

legal_issues.text: Whether the will Ex.A dated August 22, 1945, executed by Lakshmamma was genuine, validly executed when she was in sound and disposing state of mind, and represented her intentions.
Whether Lakshmamma had absolute title/competency to bequeath the suit properties (survivorship under gift/will, source of purchase moneys for items 3-5, effect of Narayana's alienations).

petitioner_arguments.text: Survivorship applied to gift deed Ex.D items 1-2 and Annaji's will bequest Rs.10,320; Sadagopalachar purchased items 3-4 with that money; all devolved to Lakshmamma by survivorship.
Alternatively, even if no survivorship, Narayana alienated properties exceeding his half share, leaving remainder as Lakshmamma's absolute property.
Will Ex.A genuine, executed voluntarily in sound mind; proved by attesting witnesses PW1-2, scribe PW3, Junior Kalbagal PW4, appellant PW7; instructions given year before and during illness.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 67,68 Evidence Act; presumption on proof of signature

respondent_arguments.text: No will by Annaji 1901; gift deed Ex.D no survivorship; Lakshmamma transferred her interest in gift properties to Sadagopalachar, who became sole owner; items 3-5 purchased with Sadagopalachar's own funds.
Narayana Iyengar absolute owner after father's death; Lakshmamma incompetent to will any properties.
Will Ex.A not genuine/valid; Lakshmamma not sound mind; procured by appellant's machinations.

court_reasoning.text: Proof of wills requires signature, sound disposing mind, understanding of contents/effect, free will; like documents but with solemnity; suspicious circumstances (unnatural dispositions, propounder prominent role/benefit) require clear removal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Initial onus discharged by essential proof, but suspicious circumstances make onus heavy.

court_reasoning.text: Suspicious: elaborate argumentative preamble (artificial, some untrue e.g. Rs.3000 advance); exclusion of grandchildren for small Rs.500 each despite Narayana's prior gifts; substantial benefits to appellant's sons (adopted uncle's sons, improbable over own grandchildren); appellant prepared draft, dictated, no independent evidence of instructions/approval.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Will features improbable/unfair; appellant's prominent role unremoved suspicion.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence unsatisfactory: discrepancies (PW2 presence, reading); no clear proof will read fully/approved; appellant's instructions story afterthought; no draft produced; scribe relative; PW4 not fully disinterested (brother R5 benefits).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No satisfactory proof Lakshmamma understood/approved contents.

court_reasoning.text: High Court obiter on title issues not justified as will failure moots them; not decided here.

holdings.text: Will not proved due/validly executed; appellant failed to remove suspicions; High Court finding upheld.
Issues on Lakshmamma's title/competency not decided.

precedents_cited.relevance: Classic rules: onus on propounder to satisfy court; propounder benefit/preparation excites suspicion requiring removal.
Benefit and role in preparation throws onus to show righteousness; no inflexible rule if mind competent and will read.
Suspicion rule extends beyond propounder preparation/benefit to all suspicious circumstances.
Chief beneficiary leading role requires suspicion removal, clear proof of approval.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Propounder must remove all suspicions even without undue influence plea.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas
precedents_cited.relevance: Manager/adviser role in simple will insufficient proof of understanding.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi
precedents_cited.relevance: No suspicion if natural beneficiary role.
Solicitor beneficiary onus discharged on evidence despite prudence suggestion.
Sound mind at instructions suffices if accepts execution believing faithful.
Reasonable scepticism, not incredulity; respect trial judge credibility.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption on signature rebuttable by suspicions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Proof of documents, signature, handwriting, attestation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Sound mind for will; signing, attestation requirements.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court's dismissal of the suit, holding the will not proved validly executed due to suspicious circumstances not removed; title issues left undecided.
outcome.costs: No orders as to costs mentioned

key_quotes.text: "the onus probandi lies in every case upon the party propounding a will and he must satisfy the conscience of the court that the instrument so propounded is the last will of a free and capable testator."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Classic rule from Barry v. Butlin on propounder's onus.

key_quotes.text: if a party writes or prepares a will under which he takes a benefit, that is a circumstance that ought generally to excite the suspicion of the court...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "where a will is charged with suspicion, the rules enjoin a reasonable scepticism, not an obdurate persistence in disbelief."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Balanced approach from Harmes v. Hinkson.
